translation.en: Black service in the military began to change white racial attitudes.
translation.ko: 흑인의 군 복무는 인종 차별적이던 백인의 사고방식을 바꿔나갔습니다

"We want a country which shall not brand the Declaration of Independence as a lie.

translation.ko: '우리는 예전의 연방을 위해 싸우는 게 아니라'

That it's essential that the country

translation.en: [Bonner] Part of the hardship of the Civil War

A way to think about Gettysburg is that it's an echo

translation.ko: 여기서 링컨의 가장 유명한 말이 '자유의 새로운 탄생'이죠

translation.ko: 더글러스가 얘기했던 국가 재건이죠 자유의 새로운 탄생요

translation.ko: 둘 다 남북 전쟁을 새로운 창조로 보는 겁니다

[Bonner] Part of what he's doing in Gettysburg is helping himself

translation.en: If this is a war about the Union,

translation.ko: 너무 많은 이가 죽은 것일 수도 있죠

translation.en: But if this is a war about emancipation, if this is a war for Black freedom,
translation.ko: 하지만 해방을 위한 전쟁 흑인의 자유를 위한 전쟁이라면

translation.en: uh, then maybe Gettysburg is worth it.
translation.ko: 게티즈버그의 희생도 가치가 있는 게 됩니다

translation.ko: 여기서 링컨이 굉장히 설득력을 얻었다고 생각해요

how much a person can change.
translation.ko: 변할 수 있는지 알 수 있습니다

translation.en: For Lincoln to go from urging colonization

translation.ko: 흑인의 미래에 관해 얘기하다니 놀라운 일이죠

translation.en: [Foner] I think they came to respect one another very deeply.
translation.ko: 둘은 서로를 매우 깊이 존경하게 된 거 같아요

translation.en: They were both self-made men.
Lincoln had one year of formal schooling. Douglass had none.
translation.ko: 링컨은 정규 교육을 딱 1년 받았고 더글러스는 아예 독학했어요

translation.en: Both of them had risen to prominence through their wits, through their mind.
translation.ko: 둘 다 출세의 수단이 자신의 재치와 두뇌였고요

translation.en: Whatever they became, they made themselves into,
translation.ko: 어떤 인물이 됐든 간에 스스로 개척하여 된 거였죠

translation.en: and I think they were kind of kindred spirits in that respect.
translation.ko: 그런 면에서 둘은 비슷한 정신을 가진 거 같아요

translation.en: [Bonner] Douglass is feeling really optimistic
translation.ko: 더글러스는 흑인의 미래를 위해 링컨과 계속 일할 수 있겠다고

translation.en: that he can continue to work with Lincoln toward a Black American future.
translation.ko: 더글러스는 흑인의 미래를 위해 링컨과 계속 일할 수 있겠다고 정말 낙관적으로 생각해요

translation.en: On April 9th, 1865,
General Lee of the Confederacy surrenders to the Union,
translation.ko: 남부 연합의 리 장군이 북부 연방에 항복하면서

translation.en: marking the beginning of the end of the Civil War.
Sometimes history appoints certain people,
translation.ko: 역사는 더글러스 같은 특정인을 가끔 지목하여

translation.en: like Douglass, to be the voice of a movement,
translation.ko: 역사는 더글러스 같은 특정인을 가끔 지목하여 어떤 운동을 대변하게 합니다

translation.en: and when they can find an advocate like President Lincoln,
translation.ko: 귀를 기울이고 변화하려는 링컨 대통령 같은 지지자를

translation.en: who's willing to listen and change,
its incredible to see what those leaders can accomplish together.
translation.ko: 두 지도자는 함께 놀라운 일을 해내죠

translation.en: Unfortunately, history can also cut those relationships tragically short.
translation.ko: 안타깝게도 역사는 그런 관계를 비극적으로 금방 끝내기도 합니다

translation.en: [man] In celebration of Lee's surrender, Lincoln gave a speech
translation.ko: 리의 항복을 축하하는 자리에서 링컨은 연설했습니다

translation.en: to say that African American soldiers who had served in the Union Army
translation.ko: 링컨은 연설했습니다 북군에서 복무한 흑인 군인들에게 "제러드 매글리오카 인디애나 대학교 로스쿨 교수"

translation.ko: 그날 그 연설을 들었던 사람 중 하나가

But freedom isn't the end of the story.
translation.ko: 하지만 이 이야기는 자유에서 끝나지 않습니다

translation.en: We think of the assassination of Lincoln as a great tragedy, and it is,
translation.ko: 우리는 링컨의 암살을 엄청난 비극으로 간주하죠 사실이긴 하지만

[man] "This is a country for white men,

translation.ko: '그러니 하나님께 맹세코 제가 대통령인 한' '백인을 위한 정부가 될 겁니다'

translation.ko: 링컨과는 해와 달만큼이나 정반대라고 할 수 있어요

translation.en: [Epps] He loved the idea of big rallies.

translation.ko: 일어나서 주로 자신에 관한 긴 연설을 하는 걸 좋아했죠

translation.en: I think we've all seen political figures like this at various points in history.
translation.ko: 역사 속 다양한 시점에서 비슷한 정치인을 많이 보셨을 겁니다

translation.en: [Rahman] Once he becomes president, he more or less says upfront

translation.ko: 자신의 목표는 시민권의 희석을 막는 것이라고 말해요

translation.en: [Blight] Frederick Douglass went to the White House to visit this president.
translation.ko: 프레더릭 더글러스는 이 대통령을 만나러 백악관에 가요

translation.en: It was a terrible moment.
[Ifill] Andrew Johnson makes very clear
that he thinks that Frederick Douglass is beneath him.
translation.ko: 자기 밑에 있다고 생각한다는 점을 분명히 하죠

translation.en: He thinks Black people should be grateful to him.
"I've owned slaves, and I have bought slaves,

Practically, so far as my connection with slaves has gone,
I've been their slave instead of their being mine."

translation.ko: 프레더릭 더글러스를 만난 뒤 앤드루 존슨은 비서에게 말해요

translation.en: "I know that damn Douglass.
He's like any other nigger.
He would sooner cut a white man's throat than not."

supporting vigorous enforcement of the rights of the former slaves,
translation.ko: 앤드루 존슨이 열렬히 지지하게 만들긴 쉽지 않았겠죠

translation.en: which of course he did not do.
[man] I get it. Johnson's a racist,

translation.ko: 하지만 그런 대통령도 흑인을 해할 순 없어요

translation.en: now that slavery's been abolished.
If you hated Black people so much, you shouldn't have joined the Union.
translation.ko: 흑인이 싫다면 북부 연방에 합류하지 말았어야죠, 존슨

translation.en: Too late now.
Hold up, just because you're free, doesn't mean you're a citizen,
translation.ko: 하지만 잠깐만요 자유인이라고 해서 시민이라는 뜻은 아닙니다

translation.en: and without citizenship,
Black folks have no recourse against Southern attacks on Black freedom.
translation.ko: 남부가 자유를 공격해도 흑인들이 호소할 수단이 없죠

translation.en: As soon as the 13th is passed,

translation.en: While the name Black Code sounds like an amazing new Shonda Rhimes show,
translation.ko: "컬럼비아 특별구의 흑인 단속법" 숀다 라임스의 신작 드라마 제목 같다고요?

translation.en: uh-uh, it's anything but.
We're talking about laws.
See, many of these laws require Black people and only Black people
to sign year-long labor contracts with white employers,
translation.ko: 백인 고용주와 1년 이상의 노동 계약을 맺게 했고

translation.en: and tax them up to $100 for taking employment
as anything other than a farmer or servant.
And they even force Black children into mandatory "apprenticeships"
translation.ko: 심지어 흑인 아이들은 수습직으로 일하는 걸 의무화해서

translation.en: to keep them in the labor force. Kids!
translation.ko: 계속 노동 자원으로 쓰려고 했죠 애들을요

translation.en: Sure, while the North is outraged, these Southern legislatures basically say,
translation.ko: 북부는 분노했지만 남부의 주 의회들은 말해요 '무슨 말입니까?'

translation.en: "What are you talking about? Black Codes aren't slavery.
translation.ko: 남부의 주 의회들은 말해요 '무슨 말입니까?' '흑인 단속법은 노예제가 아녜요'

translation.en: It's an entirely different word. [scoffs] It's two words, even.
And look. They're getting paid now."
Right.
But guess what happens if a Black person refuses these new restrictions?
translation.ko: 하지만 이런 신규 제약을 흑인이 거부하면 어떻게 될까요?

translation.en: What happened if they tried to exercise their freedom?
Well, they could be taken to jail
and surprise, surprise, forced into labor…
translation.ko: 아니나 다를까 강제 노역을 해야 해요

translation.en: without pay.
The New York Herald Tribune even runs this headline:
"South Carolina Re-establishing Slavery."
Can you imagine?
Black folks just fought, and won, an entire war for their freedom,
translation.ko: 흑인들은 자유를 위해 전쟁에서 싸워 이겼건만

translation.en: and this is what they get?
The 13th Amendment isn't gonna cut it. Question is, what will?
translation.ko: 수정 헌법 제13 조로는 어림도 없죠 그럼 도대체 무엇이면 될까요?

translation.en: Enter John Bingham, an Ohio Congressman.
translation.ko: 이때 오하이오의 하원 의원 존 빙엄이 등장합니다

translation.en: Bingham believes in freedom for everyone.
True freedom.
"I take exception to the abuse of the word 'nigger.'
To me, it does not denote color of skin,
but designates a class of creatures by the color of their souls.
translation.ko: '영혼의 색으로 규정되는 특정 인간 계급을 뜻합니다'

translation.en: Those who set their feet upon defenseless fellow men
and convert them into what we call a 'slave.'
These man-stealers,
though their skins be as white as the driven snow,
are the real niggers."
He's looking at what's happening in the South, like,
translation.ko: 그는 남부에서 벌어지는 사태를 보고 이렇게 말해요

translation.en: "Y'all, it's not looking too good down there."
He's like, "We have to do something. We have to amend the Constitution.
translation.ko: 뭔가 손을 써야 한다며 헌법을 수정해야 하고

translation.en: Provide them equal citizenship."
[Blight] John Bingham, among others,
led the way to argue for and craft the heart of the 14th Amendment.
translation.ko: 다른 누구보다도 존 빙엄은 수정 헌법 제14 조의 핵심으로 사람들을 이끌었습니다

translation.en: What Bingham wants is to do exactly what Frederick Douglass called for
translation.ko: 빙엄이 하려는 건 정확히 프레더릭 더글러스가

translation.en: in his Fourth of July speech:
Make America live up to its promise,
translation.ko: 미국이 자신의 약속에 부응하게 하는 것

translation.en: to expand American citizenship in the Constitution,
to right the wrongs of Dred Scott
and secure the blessings of equality for all in writing
so no one can ever take them away.
translation.ko: 아무도 빼앗을 수 없게 하는 것이었습니다

translation.en: To do that, Bingham and a group of radical Republicans
translation.ko: 이를 위해 빙엄과 급진적 공화당원 몇몇이

translation.en: build 14 to include many of the rights that were denied to Black Americans.
translation.ko: 흑인에게는 부정되었던 권리의 대부분을 포함하는 14조를 만들죠

translation.en: And they fight to make 14 a constitutional amendment.
translation.ko: 그리고 이 14조를 수정 헌법으로 만들기 위해 싸워요

translation.en: That's important, because they understand that they won't always be in charge.
translation.ko: 자신들이 평생 의회에 있는 게 아니니 헌법으로 만드는 게 중요하죠

translation.en: The next guys might want it gone.
Now, amendments are extremely difficult to pass,
but they're also very hard to get rid of.
-And Bingham succeeds. -[fireworks explode]
In 1868, the 14th Amendment officially becomes
a part of the Constitution.
And it proves that the United States is on board
translation.ko: 미국이 모두를 위한 평등이라는 새로운 임무를

translation.en: with this new mission of equality for all.
"All persons born or naturalized in the United States
and subject to the jurisdiction thereof,
translation.ko: '미국의 행정 관할권 내에 있는 모든 사람은'

translation.en: are citizens of the United States and of the state wherein they reside."
[Epps] If you look at the language, it's quite striking.
"Person born in the United States,"
translation.ko: 미국에서 출생한 사람이라고 되어 있을 뿐

translation.en: and there's no other restriction.
It doesn't say a white person born in the United States.
Therefore, people of African descent are citizens.
"No state shall make or enforce any law which shall abridge the privileges
translation.ko: '어떠한 주도 미국 시민의 특권과 면책권을' '박탈하는 법률을'

translation.en: or immunities of citizens of the United States."
[Epps] What this means is that the first eight amendments to the US Constitution,
translation.ko: 이건 미국 수정 헌법의 첫 8개 조항인

translation.en: what we call the Bill of Rights,
all citizens have those rights,
and have them against state governments as well as the federal government.
translation.ko: 연방 정부뿐 아니라 주 정부에 대해서도요

translation.en: "Nor shall any state deprive any person of life, liberty, or property
translation.ko: '어떠한 주도 정당한 법의 절차에 의하지 아니하고는'

translation.en: without due process of law."
[Bonner] Black people, from the Antebellum Period,
have been trying to use courts to get what they want.
translation.ko: 법정을 이용해 원하는 걸 얻으려 애썼어요

translation.en: They want to be able to defend themselves against violence.
translation.ko: 폭력에 맞서 자신을 지킬 수 있길 바랐죠

translation.en: And now the 14th Amendment says that,
yes, you can go to court if something happens.
translation.ko: 법원에 갈 수 있다고 수정 헌법 제14 조가 말합니다

translation.en: "Nor deny to any person within its jurisdiction
translation.ko: '그 관할권 내에 있는 어떠한 사람에 대해서도'

translation.en: the equal protection of the laws."
translation.ko: '법률에 의한 동등한 보호를 거부할 수 없다'

translation.en: [man] Citizenship becomes so clearly delineated
that citizenship was automatic,
that full citizenship, not three-fifths, not conditional--
translation.ko: 3/5이 아닌 완전한 시민권을 조건 없이 준다고 합니다

translation.en: The moment you breathe that first breath of American air, you're an American.
translation.ko: 태어나 처음 들이마신 공기가 미국의 공기면 미국인이 되는 거죠

translation.en: If you are born here, you are born with all of the liberties
and the protections of US citizenship.
[Foner] It overturns the Dred Scott decision,
which said Black people could not be citizens,
no matter where they were born, even if they'd been here for generations.
translation.ko: 시민이 될 수 없다고 했던 드레드 스콧 판결을 뒤집는 거죠

translation.en: The 14th Amendment is absolutely pivotal.
translation.ko: 수정 헌법 제14 조는 절대적으로 중요합니다

translation.en: in moving us from a white male nation
translation.ko: "켈리 라이틀 에르난데스 UCLA 역사학자" 백인 남성의 나라였던 미국이

translation.en: into a future in which there was a possibility
translation.ko: 민주주의 내에서 다양성을 지닐 가능성이 있는 미래로

translation.en: for diversity within our democracy.
translation.ko: 민주주의 내에서 다양성을 지닐 가능성이 있는 미래로 발전하는 것이니까요

translation.en: [Ifill] The 14th Amendment also includes the first time that the word…
translation.ko: 수정 헌법 제14 조는 '동등'이라는 단어를 처음으로

translation.en: "equal" is used in the Constitution.
And it becomes enshrined in our Constitution.
translation.ko: 이 단어는 미국 헌법에서 소중히 간직되죠

translation.en: In a lot of ways our country wasn't founded in 1776.
translation.ko: 많은 면에서 우리 미국은 1776년에 건국된 게 아닙니다

translation.en: It was founded when John Bingham and the Congress passes the 14th Amendment
translation.ko: 존 빙엄과 의회가 수정 제14 조를 통과시켰을 때 건국됐죠

translation.en: because that's the modern Constitution.
[Bonner] Douglass and others recognize that the 14th Amendment has
translation.ko: 더글러스와 다른 사람들은 수정 헌법 제14 조가

translation.en: changed the way the nation's laws will work.
translation.ko: 미국 법의 작용 방식을 바꿨다는 걸 인정해요

translation.en: It's not viewed uncritically,
but it is cause of tremendous celebration.
This is a moment of incredible optimism.
[Ifill] African Americans are filled with this excitement
about what it means to be full citizens.
After the passage of the 14th Amendment,
there is this belief and excitement that we've hit the reset button
translation.ko: 리셋 버튼을 눌렀다는 믿음과 흥분이 흘러넘쳐요

translation.en: on a badly mismanaged project… [chuckles]
…and America is now going to step into her own.
translation.ko: 이제 미국은 자기만의 길로 나가는 겁니다

translation.en: One of the biggest successes is the flourishing of Black education.
translation.ko: 가장 큰 성공은 흑인 교육이 꽃을 피운 거죠

translation.en: People in the South build up institutions
translation.ko: 글을 읽고 쓰는 능력이 중요하니 남부의 흑인들은

translation.en: for their own education because of the importance of literacy.
translation.ko: 글을 읽고 쓰는 능력이 중요하니 남부의 흑인들은 자체 교육 기관을 세워요

translation.en: Black people spend a few million dollars of their own money for education,
translation.ko: 흑인들이 교육에 손수 몇백만 달러를 씁니다

translation.en: and these are people in the South who had no money.
translation.ko: 예전의 남부에서는 돈 한 푼 없던 흑인들이죠

translation.en: [Ifill] Frederick Douglass,
you just say his name, and to me it's like a prayer.
translation.ko: 그 이름만 들어도 제겐 기도 같죠

translation.en: He was remarkable in that he had an aptitude
translation.ko: 억제할 수 없는 적성이 있었다는 점에서

translation.en: that could not be contained.
He didn't want Black people to just be free from slavery.
translation.ko: 단순히 흑인들이 노예 신분에서 벗어나길 바란 게 아니었죠

translation.en: He wanted them to be full citizens.
What an extraordinary man and human being.
[as Douglass] "I seem to be living in a new world.
Who could have imagined what has occurred?
The great triumph of justice and liberty, not only for the slaves emancipated,
translation.ko: '정의와 자유라는 위대한 승리' '노예가 해방되었을 뿐 아니라'

translation.en: but a Civil Rights bill, the right to vote.
All for a class stigmatized but a little while ago
as worthless goods and chattel,
but now regarded as men,
recognized as such before the law."
[narrator] Frederick Douglass.
Enslaved person,
fugitive,
free non-citizen,
citizen.
But his incredible journey doesn't end there.
translation.ko: 하지만 그의 놀라운 여정은 거기서 끝나지 않습니다

translation.en: Throughout his long life,
Frederick Douglass would continue to champion the rights
of Black Americans, women, and immigrants,
and the impact of his fight has echoed through generations.
translation.ko: 그 싸움의 영향은 대대손손 울림을 주었죠

translation.en: Even today.
[news anchor] These images show the crane and a flatbed truck
translation.ko: 지금 보시는 장면은 기중기와 평상형 트럭으로

translation.en: removing the statue of Roger B. Taney
translation.ko: 로저 B. 터니의 동상을 금요일 꼭두새벽에

translation.en: in the wee hours of the morning Friday.
So he said Blacks were so far inferior
translation.ko: 흑인은 너무나 열등해서 백인이 누려야 하는 권리를

translation.en: that they had "no rights which the white man was bound to respect."
translation.ko: 흑인은 너무나 열등해서 백인이 누려야 하는 권리를 누릴 수 없다고 하셨죠 "찰스 터니 3세"

translation.en: So we asked that night for forgiveness and…
translation.ko: 그래서 우린 그날 밤 용서를 구했고

translation.en: the Scotts embraced us and forgave us.
translation.ko: 스콧 가족은 우릴 포옹하고 용서했어요 "린 잭슨 드레드 스콧의 후손"

translation.en: There were people in my family who said,
"I don't know if I want to meet those people."
translation.ko: '난 그 사람들 별로 만나고 싶지 않아'

translation.en: And the unexpected and impromptu apology was given.
translation.ko: 그런데 예상치 못한 사과를 즉석에서 받았어요

translation.en: I have cousins who were in tears.
When that starts to happen
and you get to level of understanding and relationship,
other things become possible.
We can all do something like that.
If the Scotts and the Taneys can reconcile, can't you?
translation.ko: 스콧과 터니 가족도 화해하는데 누군들 못 할까요?

translation.en: [Stevenson] We talk about equality a lot in America.
We talk about justice.
We have a Pledge of Allegiance that has these words,
and the 14th Amendment was intended to make that vision real.
translation.ko: 수정 헌법 제14 조는 그런 이상을 현실로 만들려 했죠

translation.en: What we didn't account for…
is how unprepared we were to actually embrace true equality.
translation.ko: 진정한 평등을 실제로 포용하기엔 준비되지 않은 상태였단 겁니다

translation.en: I pledge that I will never accept the false teachings
translation.ko: 모든 인종이 평등하거나 같다는 그릇된 가르침을 절대로 받아들이지 않겠습니다

translation.en: that all races equal or the same.
-[woman] No justice! -[protesters] No peace!
All we say to America is, be true to what you said on paper.
translation.ko: 미국에 하고 싶은 말은 명문화된 걸 지키란 것뿐입니다

translation.en: As soon as the 14th is ratified, it's attacked.
translation.ko: 수정 헌법 제14 조는 비준되자마자 공격당합니다

translation.en: In the courts, in the streets, even in our history books.
Why haven't we learned the story of the 14th Amendment?
translation.ko: 수정 헌법 제14 조의 이야기를 우리는 왜 안 배웠을까요?

translation.en: Because there are a lot of people out there who fought very hard
to make sure you'd never know.
